comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: "Haverty" seems more plausible a name--the original caption looks like "Mrs. C. Haverty." If that's correct, this might be Mrs. Clarence Haverty, wife of a Georgia furniture company owner? research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord2.php?-action... Mrs. Clarence Haverty is mentioned in the society pages of the Atlanta Constitution in 1913, as having been to New York with her husband that year.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Thanks for pointing out the typo.  We'll fix it next time we update records.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: No, this is Mrs. Catharine Haverty of New York City, a widow, and the owner and manager of a 60-cab taxicab company. She is attempting to buck a 1913 New York City strike of unionized taxicab drivers by hiring non-union drivers, and has defied threats, to announce that she will ride at the head of her company's parade of vehicles during the strike. The above photo of Mrs. Haverty, with her driver and vigilant bodyguards, is dated the day after the appearance of this New York Times report of November 13, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E0D71E3EE233A...

comment.author: 96179722@N00
comment._content: Dang.  I thought it was our Mrs Haverty.  I work in a hospital built at the location of the old Haverty house in Atlanta.  We have all kinds of information about the Haverty family in our archives.
